Dear Ken:
Welcome back! I’m delighted to hear of your new appoint¬
ment with NASB. Things keep getting better and better for you. This,
latest assignment certainly sounds like you1re going to be involved
in something very crucial and at the same time very exciting (not
that your prior work abroad wasn't significant as well).
To business first. I was.very interested in the details of
what you’ll be trying to 'do with-•programming- for the culturally and
economically disadvantaged. Like many other educational media people
I’m anxious to have a hand in this ‘challange. And perhaps KFJC-FM
in its own way can make a contribution. Enclosed is a copy of an
initial proposal for programs that we could air starting in the Fall.
Actually, the ground-work for ..this activity was initiated last Spring,
anticipating as it were the-kind of committment that you and NAEB
seem to be making'. , .
Cal Flint suddenly awoke to the general seriousness of the
situation and budgeted $50,000 this year to implement a program at
Foothill. This amount, while not an overwhelming sum for this kind
of program nonetheless is-quite significant when one considers the
very "tight” financial situation which now prevails over our rather
expensive 2-campus operation (Foothill is no longer acting like the
rich College of a few years back). Flint has appointed two full¬
time directors to the program who've set up a committee to investigate,
advise and assist in the set-up for our district. Right now the
information is just starting to come in. Questions as to whom exactly
are we trying to help, and just how can Foothill provide them with
help are naturally utmost in everyone’s mind. What will be the most
effective way to get the show on the road (once it’s decided what
we can do) must also be resolved.... all the kinds of questions, I’m
sure, that you’re confronting right now. It shall be interesting indeed
to see what response is forthcoming to our overtures.
Just how the radio broadcasts will fit in to the overall
scheme is anyone’s quess right now. I came up with 2 program ideas
(see the enclosure) which can be easily, and I think effectively
produced. Naturally they'll have to be well-publicized and run long
enough for a word-of-mouth kind of publicity to materialize. The
